Posts.Content: Hi Jen. I'm not surprised you're stressed. Its all such a shock and a scary journey. I don't know what the official guide lines are but I was diagnosed on 14th may, had surgery in 9th June and started chemo on 9th July. That seems to be usual in this area. Goods luck.
Posts.Title: waiting and more waiting :(

Posts.Content: Hi Amy I wore shirts for a while as they were easier to get on. I got some pyjamas with a shirt top for the hospital stay but didn't use whilst in hospital as stayed in the hospital gown.  Good luck
Posts.Title: Practical post mastectomy stuff

Posts.Content: Hi Headwitch Like you, I didn't discover the on-line community for a while. I'd had the op, chemo and rads before i joined, just left with Herceptin and Tamoxifen now. I don't post very often but I check the discussions obsessively every day !! I think it helps to put things into place just knowing that there are others are out there. Hope you can enjoy the weekend.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Hi Worried I put on a stone whilst having chemo but I have maintained the same weight for the last 12 months whilst on Tamoxifen. This years task is to get back to my pre BC weight !
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and weight gain

Posts.Content: Hi Jo Radiotherapy is definitely better than chemo!  I moisturised with E45 every morning and evening from before the first session until a few months after the last one, and my skin survived well. Good luck.
Posts.Title: 1st Radiotherapy session tomorrow...really scared

Posts.Content: Hi I guess we can only hurt the ones we love. Being diagnosed with cancer feels like a death sentence at first and the list of appointments and treatment seems to go on for ever. Maybe your partner feels at the moment that she doesn't want to hold you back from all the things you could do with your life so is trtimg to let yoi go. Hopefully things will settle down as time goes on. ...... Just be there for when she needs you
Posts.Title: Emotions

Posts.Content: Welcome back LondonLass! Hope you feel well again soon xx
Posts.Title: THANKYOU SO MUCH

Posts.Content: Hi Raspo99 I certainly don't wash mine every day! I do keep them in their boxes though. When I went away I just used my softies inside a selection of pocketed vest tops. I don't know why but I tend to only wear the prothesis when working and the softies at weekends!
Posts.Title: Protheses problems?

Posts.Content: Hi Phaedra That's a tricky one ! I guess everyone is different and anyone that is feeling fine probably isn't posting! I went back to work two weeks after my rads finished (January 2016) and haven't had any sick days off work since. It was hard to start off with though as it wasn't until I was back in the work environment that I realised that "chemo brain" was still with me! Nearly two years on I have a normal head of hair (hoorah) and I have got back to below my pre-cancer weight.  If you have the determination you will be fine, but just remember that; it is OK to have bad days; and to be kind to yourself! Hugs Callie
Posts.Title: Finishing treatment..

Posts.Content: Hi I was sick yesterday evening and again this morning so haven't had my tamoxifen today (I usually have it with breakfast). What are the implications of missing a day or two ?
Posts.Title: Sickness bug / Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi worried2016 Thanks for your reply. I'm feeling a bit better today so am planning on getting out of bed !! I've been taking if for about a year now without any major problems. I get mild hot flushes and a bit of 'brain fog' but that could still be the chemo slowly working its way out. I hope you find it OK too. Happy Christmas x
Posts.Title: Sickness bug / Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Blue I was told that only doctors were allowed to take blood from the foot. I've only had the nodes removed on one side but on one occasion they just couldn't find a decent vein in the other arm. The phlebotomist had to give in but a doctor was called. I was an in patient at the time.
Posts.Title: Blood tests in foot due to node removal on both sides.

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky I don't know about Carboplatin but I did have weekly Paclitaxol for six weeks as i had an allergic reaction to the docetaxol. I found having it weekly was a lot better as the dose was smaller. I still felt nauseous but was never actually sick, which I had been with the FEC and Docetaxol. I was able to work from home every day except the acutal chemo day. Hope it goes ok for you.
Posts.Title: Weekly Paclitaxol & 3 weekly Carboplatin

Posts.Content: I've done it and the results were pretty depressing. Then I helped my daughter with her maths homework about Probability and realised that as there are two possible outcomes the chances of surviving or not surviving 5 years are 50 50. A statistic for every occasion!!
Posts.Title: Predict

Posts.Content: Hi Anne Thanks for your reply. I'm on Tamoxifen and also have two Herceptin left. It's probably nothing but you know how easy it is to worry! C
Posts.Title: Wrist pain (worried about secondary BC)

Posts.Content: Hi I finished chemo in November and rads in December. I have had an intermittent pain in my wrist for over a month now so should probably get it checked out.  Who should I call - GP, BCN, onco? I have a follow up appointment with onco on 28th Sept. Shall I leave it till then?
Posts.Title: Wrist pain (worried about secondary BC)

Posts.Content: Hi Does anyone have experience of delayed reconstruction after a double mastectomy? I had my op in June 2015 and out of the blue a surgeon mentioned it at an appointment last week. I thought that I wasn't really bothered about it but now enough time has passed since the original diagnosis, perhaps I would like to be 'normal' again. I've looked at the booklet and it mentions that more than one operation may be required to get the new one the same as the old one, so will it be a better result and less hassle as they will both be new? I had chemo and rads in 2015 so think it will be some type of flap recon. Any comments greatly appreciated! Love to all.
Posts.Title: Delayed reconstruction after bilateral mastectomy

Posts.Content: Oh JoJo I feel for you. My daughter was 13 when I was diagnosed. We thought about not telling her straight away but decided against it as I was having trouble keeping it together. Telling her was the worst thing ever but I promised not to keep anything from her and made her promise to ask me if she wanted to know anything and not use Google. I think teenagers will worry more if they think you are keepo something from them.  I also told the school at the earliest opportunity and they were brilliant. Sending more hugs.
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Hi Kizzi. I'm not surprised you're upset and angry, all that sounds like a nightmare. All I can say is that I have been on Tamoxifen since December and haven't had any side effects to speak of - the occasional hot flush but nothing else. Give them a go and hopefully you'll be lucky too.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer 2014

Posts.Content: Nice poem. Congratulations on completing your treatment.
Posts.Title: End of treatment....!

Posts.Content: Wow! You sound really organised -well done ! I had extra slickness pills for my second chemo and it made all the difference. Good luck for tomorrow! Xx
Posts.Title: 2nd chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi I'm on Herceptin for HER2 at the moment and haven't had any nasty side effects. It can be given as an injection so hardly takes any time at all. Best wishes
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Hi.  I had a similar diagnosis in May last year except my tumors were too large for a lumpectomy so I had a bilateral mastectomy first then all the chemo / radiotherapy / Herceptin / hormone therapy.  It's a lot to take in isn't it. One minute you're a normal person then all this hits you. But it  is doable - sure, some of it is unpleasant but the op wasn't particularly painful - more uncofortable. Just take one day at a time and be kind to yourself.  You need time to get get used to the diagnosis.  There is loads of helpful info on this site and Cancer Research UK.  Beware of just using Google though as there is a lot of rubbish out there too. I'm sure you'll get a better reply from one of the regulars soon.  Take care.
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed with HRE2+ AND ER+ breast cancer

Posts.Content: That's brilliant - I hadn't noticed the irony of a 'frozen' shoulder !!!! Xxx
Posts.Title: NOT Pink and Fluffy! RETURNS....

Posts.Content: Can we add an endurance event?! I have a frozen shoulder so getting layers on or off is a bit problematic - I try to just wait if out ! Thanks for your post it's good to have some humour!
Posts.Title: NOT Pink and Fluffy! RETURNS....
